module.name: decision_support
module.keywords: module, requirements, systems engineering, trade studies, analysis, verification, validation, justification

change.description: Removed application module ISO 10303-233 systems engineering specific detail from Annex F Application module implementation and usage guide.

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of decision support activities and information.
Hyperlink to Annex F for ISO 10303-233 concept model introductory material associated with decision support capabilities enabled within ISO 10303-233.

inscope.li: items within the scope of application module ;
items within the scope of application module ;
trade studies with measures of effectiveness;
facility to assign activity information to decision support data;
facility to assign analysis and condition information to decision support data;
facility to assign authorization information to decision support data;
facility to assign classification and identification information to decision support data;
facility to assign date and time information to decision support data;
facility to assign documentation information to decision support data;
facility to assign person and organization information to decision support data;
facility to assign project information to decision support data;
facility to assign property information to decision support data;
facility to assign verification evidence information to decision support data.

refdata_subclause.title: ARM Classifications of Requirement_version
refdata_subclause.p: A may be classified in order to specify it's intended interpretation and usage in accordance with the industrial needs as specified by INCOSE.

Figure 6.1 shows
classifications for the purpose of allocation..

refdata_subclause.title: MeasureOfEffectiveness
refdata_subclause.p: A Measure of effectiveness states an optimization condition that a system shall meet. One of the two subclasses shall be used to signify the optimization direction.

refdata_subclause.title: MeasureOfEffectivenessMaximize
refdata_subclause.p: A Measure of effectiveness stating that the condition shall be maximized.

refdata_subclause.title: MeasureOfEffectivenessMinimize
refdata_subclause.p: A Measure of effectiveness states that the condition shall be minimized.

refdata_subclause.title: FunctionalRequirement
refdata_subclause.p: An Functional requirement states what the system shall be done by the system to which it is allocated.

refdata_subclause.title: ImposedDesignRequirement
refdata_subclause.p: An Imposed design requirement states particular elements that shall be used in the design of the system or part.

refdata_subclause.title: InterfaceRequirement
refdata_subclause.p: An Interface requirement states the characteristics of the interface to which it is assigned.

refdata_subclause.title: PerformanceRequirement
refdata_subclause.p: An Performance requirement states a time duration or a time probability for the completion of a functional requirement or a function as a modelling element.

refdata_subclause.title: PhysicalPropertyRequirement
refdata_subclause.p: An Physical property requirement states a physical property that shall be exhibited by the system or system assembly to which it is assigned.

refdata_subclause.title: ReferenceRequirement
refdata_subclause.p: An Reference requirement states a reference to a source of additional requirements that shall be met by the system or part.

refdata_subclause.title: ValidationRequirement
refdata_subclause.p: An Verification requirement states how a system requirement, design or instance shall be shown by the development organization to meet stakeholder needs.

refdata_subclause.title: VerificationRequirement
refdata_subclause.p: An Verification requirement states how a system design or instance shall be shown by the development organization using test, analysis, inspection , demonstration, simulation, similarity, sampling, or other method to meet a requirement allocated to the system.

example.p: The following shows how the Requirement_version categorization elements would appear in an ISO 10303-21 instance data file.
The following shows how the Requirement_version can be represented using an OWL ontology and the related RDF/XML Abbreviated syntax.

refdata_subclause.title: Classifications of Value with unit
refdata_subclause.p: Decision support for many applications relies on access to a variety of absolute and relative measures of property value. Within many application domains there exists useful classifications for focused purpose. For example within the domain of systems engineering a system evolves through a series of life cycle stages from concept to disposal. The following reference data classifications provide a useful way of classifying property values as the system evolves from stakeholder need to realization and delivery.
Relative to this systems engineering example, Figure 6.2 shows classifications of property value useful for decision support.
In support of the systems engineering need to clearly distinguish between these decision support property value views, may be classified in order to specify its intended interpretation and usage.

refdata_subclause.title: Calculated property value
refdata_subclause.p: A Calculated property value is a property value of a whole calculated or estimated from the values of the parts that assemble to make the whole.

refdata_subclause.title: Measured property value
refdata_subclause.p: A Measured property value is a property value established by measurement of an actual part.

refdata_subclause.title: Required budgeted property value
refdata_subclause.p: A Required budgeted property value is a property value allocated to a part by a requirement, or budgeted to that part by analysis.

refdata_subclause.title: Target budget property value
refdata_subclause.p: A Target budget property value is a temporary property value used by a designer as the design work proceeds and different design alternatives are considered.

example.p: The following shows how the budgeted property values would appear in an ISO 10303-21 instance data file.
The following shows how the Property_value can be represented using an OWL ontology and the related RDF/XML Abbreviated syntax.

refdata_subclause.title: Classifications of Activity
refdata_subclause.p: Relative to this systems engineering example, Figure 6.3 illustrates the verification process.
Relative to this systems engineering example, Figure 6.4 illustrates the validation process.
In support of the systems engineering need to clearly distinguish between decision support activities, may be classified in order to specify its intended interpretation and usage.

refdata_subclause.title: Validation procedure
refdata_subclause.p: A Validation procedure describes the process used to compare a requirement against stakeholder needs.

refdata_subclause.title: Verification procedure
refdata_subclause.p: A Verification procedure describes the process used to compare a requirement against the test, analysis, or inspection results of a design or instance of a system,

example.p: The following shows how the decision support activities would appear in an ISO 10303-21 instance data file.
The following shows how the Decision_support_activity can be represented using an OWL ontology and the related RDF/XML Abbreviated syntax.

usage_guide.p: The capabilities associated with the decision support modules provide for:

ol.li: the documentation used to justify decisions;
the data concerning verification and validation;
the requirements along with information rights, documents, requirement sources, classifications, effectivity, and requirement assignment;
the traceability and collection of requirements;
trades studies with a measures of effectiveness decision support capability.

usage_guide.p: Three arms are used to relate an interface to analysis. They are: External_analysis_representation_arm, Analysis_assignment_arm, and Analysis_characterized_arm. These arms store the data a tool user needs to specify the equation to solve, where in the total system model to pick up the needed parameter values, and where to return the computed values. This capability underlies all of performance calculation, trade studies, and verification and validation.

Versioning and version relationships are needed not only by requirements, but also by many other elements of the total system model. Consequently they are defined once for an entity called “Product” and then inherited from that entity through the software mechanism of subclasses. The best way to think about product is as thing or anything. In consequence, the versioning and version relationships are in an ARM called Requirement_identification_and_version_arm that inherits from arms Product_version_arm and then from Product_view_definition_arm.

The concepts of tracing among entities and collecting them into groups is also pervasive. Consequently the traceability and collection of requirements is supported by the Requirement_view_definition_relationship_arm that inherits from the Product_view_definition_relationship_arm.

Trade studies and Measures of effectiveness (MOEs) are supported by reference data. A trade study is a class of activity and an MOE is a class of requirement version. The weighting of MOE's in the regularization function of a trade study are represented by properties on the relationship between the MOE and the trade study. The direction of optimization (maximize or minimize) is represented by a subclass of the MOE classification.

From the perspective of information cross coupling; the type extend lists identified within this module specify how all decision support information modelling concepts defined within the schemas of the decision support domain are coupled together via type extends within the decision support domain.
usage_guide.note: A large repository of information relevant to users and implementers of the STEP capabilities used in common by ISO 10303-239 and 80% of ISO 10303-233 is at .
